title: How to Explore a Tidal Pool

steps.headline: Learn beforehand by checking out an illustrated guide to local tidepool organisms.
steps.description: Guidebooks with rich photographs, such as those published by the Audubon Society, offer a way for adults and kids to visually identify and learn about organisms.

steps.headline: Get a beach etiquette guide, which can be found online or through a conservation organization, such as an aquarium or the Parks Department.
steps.description: This serves as a handy way to establish basic beach behavior rules, such as how to handle wildlife, and can be brought to the beach.

steps.headline: Establish rules ahead of time.
steps.description:
Make sure you and your companions
keep an eye out for ocean hazards, such as sudden squalls or floating logs. respect the space of other beach-goers. bring your own trash container to avoid littering. avoid damaging sensitive habitat areas. handle wildlife appropriately, and avoid sensitive species

steps.headline: Dress for adventure.
steps.description: Make sure you're wearing old clothes that you don't mind getting wet, sandy, and muddy. You can either use waterproof sandals or tall boots, depending on the weather. Also be sure to bring a change of dry clothes, a hat, waterproof sunscreen, and a bucket.

steps.headline: Keep your guide handy so you can identify organisms as you see them.
Watch where you walk, because rocks are often slippery with algae.
steps.description: Also make sure not to step on sea life!

steps.headline: Fill your bucket with sea water so you can use it to hold small animals such as snails or crabs for closer examination.
steps.description: Be sure to only keep the animal in the bucket for a few minutes before returning it to it's original home.

steps.headline: Touch animals gently with one wet finger.
Pick up animals gently, and leave alone any that offer resistance.
steps.description: Sea stars, oysters, mussels, and anemones are usually best left where they are. Crabs, cockles, snails, and sea cucumbers can be picked up.

text:
Before You Go Learn beforehand by checking out an illustrated guide to local tidepool organisms. Guidebooks with rich photographs, such as those published by the Audubon Society, offer a way for adults and kids to visually identify and learn about organisms. Get a beach etiquette guide, which can be found online or through a conservation organization, such as an aquarium or the Parks Department. This serves as a handy way to establish basic beach behavior rules, such as how to handle wildlife, and can be brought to the beach. Establish rules ahead of time. Make sure you and your companions
keep an eye out for ocean hazards, such as sudden squalls or floating logs. respect the space of other beach-goers. bring your own trash container to avoid littering. avoid damaging sensitive habitat areas. handle wildlife appropriately, and avoid sensitive species Dress for adventure. Make sure you're wearing old clothes that you don't mind getting wet, sandy, and muddy. You can either use waterproof sandals or tall boots, depending on the weather. Also be sure to bring a change of dry clothes, a hat, waterproof sunscreen, and a bucket. At the Tidepool Keep your guide handy so you can identify organisms as you see them.  Watch where you walk, because rocks are often slippery with algae. Also make sure not to step on sea life! Fill your bucket with sea water so you can use it to hold small animals such as snails or crabs for closer examination. Be sure to only keep the animal in the bucket for a few minutes before returning it to it's original home. Touch animals gently with one wet finger.  Pick up animals gently, and leave alone any that offer resistance. Sea stars, oysters, mussels, and anemones are usually best left where they are. Crabs, cockles, snails, and sea cucumbers can be picked up.
